intro: Leptorkis parishii, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its strap-like leaves that form dense clumps. The plant produces small, inconspicuous greenish-white flowers in clusters during the summer months. It is often found in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Leptorkis parishii has been historically used by Māori for its strong, fibrous leaves in the making of baskets and other woven goods.
